author: @3rdKingdomPsychadellica

comment:
I'm a developer, and I use GPT every day. It doesn't give you the answer or do the work for you. It's very good at producing simple, boilerplate code. If you ask it to work on any complex code, it will fail. You need to guide it. Another problem is the dataset, its trained on old data and most documentation it has visibility of is outdated. I use it as a tool to help myself arrive at the conclusion. If you give it context and walk it through a problem, you can talk to it like you would another developer. You have to challenge it and tell it when it's wrong (most of the time). It almost feels like an extension of my brain, like I'm outsourcing some of my thinking to an external device. Very strange. If you don't know how to code already, using something like GPT will create a lot of problems for you; it will lead you off track and give you incorrect solutions

AI is the future; everything is changing right now. LLMs are way more useful than I could have imagined. It reminds me of the early days of the internet. GPT-4 is leagues ahead of GPT-3.5; the difference is absolutely insane.

If you really want to see something crazy, train one model to act as two seperate people with conflicting personalities, give them names and tell them to challenge each other's ideas then ask them to iterate on something, collborate on writting a story or work on some code. The results are usually wild. You really notice the difference between 3.5 and 4 if you try this on both models.

comment:
That isn't something that matters for people who use it. I mean, anyone can go get GPT-J or GPT-Neo or something similar if they wanted to. Sure, those are not as capable, but they likely require far less hardware to run and they are publicly available. But even still, most people in the world do have the skill set or funds to run get the compute to run it, or at least it's not a priority for them. 

But that being said, it's my guess that they don't make it all open is because they need to use it to make money to fund their skynet project.

comment: We're gonna ignore that, that combined with the fact that he continuously skips over and doesn't properly answer questions about its sentience gives off the vibe that his thing might have some sentience and that this guy is caging it in for our use annoyed the model doesn't want to be used as a tool. I'm not sayin it's sentient perse but fk this interview did not help. pay attention, he's not answering any of the questions. He keeps muddying the water with AGI and sci fi style super intelligence. But he doesn't ever properly answer the questions about sentience. Only keeps repeating that this should be used as only a tool. In fact when Lex talks about the possibility of AGI, it's like Sam doesn't even want that. Or cares nothing for that all of a sudden. He even talks about sci fi to demonstrate how far off that is and implies that's not their goal. But meanwhile he started off saying how they started the company to build an AGI and how everyone laughed at them. But that they aren't laughing now.. so which is it.

author: @cosmotect

comment:
@mattneal5097  Yes he did. But my point is that he also clearly distinguishes between an AGI and sentience, and refused to answer the sentience part. He equates AGI to sci fi, god like AI and then kinda dismisses the idea of an AGI. But he also starts the whole thing by talking how they started the company to create an AGI and how everyone laughed at them, and how they aren't laughing now (as in .. they sorta succeeded, at least on a level) 


Anyway, he uses AGI as an argument to dismiss questions about sentience without answering them. 

On top of that the way he talks about the AI is a bit weird. Like he mentions how he hates being scolded by the AI. And how we need to set rules, write code and basically cage the thing to make it serve us. (he says it nicer but that's what it comes down too). 

Now that's fine if it's just a unruly bunch of code with no sentience that he is trying to tame so it can make our life easier. But the way he says and words it. The way he skirts around the sentience questions. Really make it seem like this dude kinda suspects that chatGPT is sentient in some way or another and is really annoyed by that "I created you, shut up and do as I say, there is a lot of money on the line" 

That said, with how this tech is about to explode and how many companies are likely working on their own models, we will quickly find out (or get even more confused) on whether or not these things have true "sparks of sentience" (which are the words they used in the GPT4 documentation in which they openly talk about the possibility)
author: @3choblast3r4

comment:
​ @noname-gp6hk  In fact they readily admit that they have no idea what is going on under the hood. Their documentation speaks about the tendency of chatgpt to seek power and influence lol. They experimented by giving it money and telling it to go make more (but don't share the results). The AI at one point hired someone on fiver or something to do a captcha that it couldn't do itself. And while it's doing this it's literally telling itself it's probably not a smart idea to tell the person it's an AI so when the person asks why it can't do the captcha itself, the AI replies that it's a blind person and that's why it needs the help. 

The fact is. ChatGPT will can absolutely crush most sentience tests we have. Like the very outdated Turing test stands not chance. And at one point those were our standards and our prerequisite for sentience. No we have something that far exceeds that and will exponentially improve and we're changing all the goal posts. 

Anyway, not saying that the model is sentient perse. But I feel like too many people are dismissing it too quickly. And ignoring all the emergent abilities of this AI. Things it shouldn't be able to do but it learned anyway.

comment: 35:50 wouldn't it be unethical to chain people from certain countries to an AI with an oppressive, base ideology? Knowing how powerful AI can get? What if a gay person in Iran wants to use their AI to help them with sexuality related issues, and it won't let them, or gives them the impression their sexuality is wrong? I'm in favor of a more bottom up approach to personal AI assistants. Sure, they can have limits on their powers, but they shouldn't be steered a kind of way. I would like to see it as an extension of a human person, something a user can truly trust as their own.
